Palau, a small island nation in the western Pacific, has officially reached herd immunity against COVID-19 as 80% of its population aged 12 and over have been fully vaccinated. This significant achievement comes after the country registered its first case on May 31, 2021, followed by a second case in June of the same year. At the time of the first case, the vast majority of Palauans, about 97% of the adult population, were already fully vaccinated, making the risk of widespread transmission low. 

Palau began implementing strict border controls early on in the pandemic, with President Thomas Remengesau Jr. suspending all charter flights from China, Macau, and Hong Kong as early as February 2020. Schools were also shut down starting in April, and the country's borders were eventually completely closed off. In January 2021, Palau began receiving COVID-19 vaccines from Operation Warp Speed as part of its membership in the Compact of Free Association with the United States. The vaccination campaign began on January 3 and reached a milestone on May 26, when an estimated 96% of adults aged 18 and over in the country were fully vaccinated.

Now that Palau has achieved herd immunity, the country is looking to further expand its vaccination program to include teenagers aged 12 to 17. Plans for this are already underway as the country reopens its borders to tourism. While vaccination is not currently mandatory for tourists, those who are not vaccinated are subject to strict quarantine rules upon arrival. Despite the successful vaccination campaign and reopening efforts, Palau continues to remain vigilant and cautious, monitoring the situation closely and maintaining strict health and safety protocols.

The bank stated that it will provide credit lines for fuel imports based on the market price for the Lebanese pound, as opposed to continuing subsidies. The move is likely to exacerbate the ongoing economic crisis in Lebanon, which began in August 2019 and has been compounded by both the COVID-19 pandemic and the 2020 Beirut port explosion. The crisis has led to a devaluation of the Lebanese pound, with the black market exchange rate reaching 15,200 LBP per USD in June 2021. Lebanon's debt to GDP ratio currently sits at 170%, and the country experienced its first-ever default in 2020. The World Bank has warned that without significant reforms, the crisis risks becoming one of the most severe economic crises in the world in the past century.

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has successfully obtained the dissolution of the House of Commons for a federal election on September 20, 2021. This election will determine the members of the House of Commons for the 44th Canadian Parliament. The Canada Elections Act allows for a fixed election date, which mandates that federal elections be held on the third Monday in October in the fourth calendar year after the polling day of the previous election. However, since the current government is a minority, the election can be held before the scheduled date if the Governor General of Canada dissolves Parliament due to a vote of no confidence or if the Prime Minister of Canada recommends a snap election. A by-election in Haldimand-Norfolk was canceled due to the election call. In the previous federal election in 2019, the Liberal Party lost its majority but won the most seats. The Conservatives continued as the Official Opposition, and the Bloc Québécois became the third party. The New Democrats lost seats but maintained official party status, and the Greens failed to achieve the required number of MPs for official party status.

The 2021 Niger attacks have continued with yet another violent incident, as gunmen attacked civilians who were praying at a mosque in the village of Theim in southwestern Niger, resulting in the deaths of 16 people. This ongoing series of attacks by militants has mainly taken place in the western region of Tillabéri, and has left a devastating death toll of 439 people, with more than 100 others injured. This marks the first time that over 100 civilians were killed in single incidents, making the January attack and the 21 March attack the deadliest against civilians in the country since the insurgency in the Maghreb began. 

Although major attacks occurred in Niger during the 2010s and 2020, it is the first year in which attacks were carried out with frequency in the country, with attacks being carried out every month of 2021. The previous biggest attack in Niger against civilians was the December 2020 Toumour attack, which resulted in 28 people killed. Both the December 2020 and January 2021 attacks were carried out during Niger's municipal and regional elections, while the February bombing specifically targeted members of the electoral commission.

The attacks are carried out by Islamist militants who arrived in the villages while crossing the border from Mali, however, the exact terrorist organization responsible is not clear. Some time before the massacre, two militants who were seen in the area were killed by the local villagers. Those attacks are suspected to have been in retaliation for those killings, according to the country's interior minister. The government of Niger has dispatched soldiers to the border after the attacks. 

On 21 February, seven members of the electoral commission were killed and three others wounded in a landmine explosion in Tillabéri, on the same day as the presidential election's second round. On 16 March, armed men on motorcycles attacked a convoy returning from a market in Banibangou by the Malian border to a nearby village in Southwestern Niger's Tillabéri Region, killing 58 people. The attacks continued on 21 March, when militants riding motorbikes attacked Intazayene, Bakorat and Wistan, three villages in the Tahoua Region close to the Malian border, killing 137 people, marking the deadliest attack committed by suspected jihadists in Niger's history. Newly elected President Mohamed Bazoum condemned the attacks and declared three days of national mourning.

The attacks have not slowed down, as on 24 March, at least 10 people were killed during attacks at two villages in the Tillabéri Region. On 18 April, at least 19 civilians were killed and two wounded when armed men raided a village in the same region. On 3 May, a military patrol was ambushed in the Tahoua Region, resulting in the killing of 16 soldiers and the wounding of six more. On 12 May, five villagers were killed and two more wounded after militants stormed the village of Fantio, in the Tillabéri region, during Eid al-Fitr celebrations. On 25 June, armed men attacked a village and nearby locations, killing a total of 19 civilians. On 29 June, Boko Haram fighters opened fire on a bus along the road between Diffa and Maine Soroa, killing three civilians, including the bus driver, two villagers and a village chief; two more were wounded. The fighters then moved on another road and opened fire on a group of soldiers, wounding six of them. A gunfight erupted, and thirteen terrorists were killed. On 2 July, around 100 heavily armed “terrorists” riding motorcycles attacked Tchoma Bangou village, killing both civilians and soldiers. 

On 25 July, fourteen people were killed and one more was wounded as gunmen stormed the village of Wiye, and on 28 July, 19 civilians were killed and five more wounded as militants stormed the village of Deye Koukou in the Banibangou area, near the border with Mali. On 1 August, Islamist militants ambushed and opened fire on a group of soldiers in Torodi, Tillabéri Region. As the soldiers were escaping and carrying the wounded, a bomb exploded, resulting in the killing of 15 soldiers, and six more went missing. Then, on 16 August, gunmen on motorbikes stormed the village of Darey-Daye in Niger, opening fire against civilians while they were tending their fields, killing 37 people, including 14 children. 

These attacks have caused widespread devastation and loss of life, and it is still unclear who is responsible for each attack. The government of Niger has dispatched soldiers to the border and has declared national mourning, but it is crucial that the situation in Niger is brought under control to prevent any further loss of life.

Operation Allies Refuge is an ongoing military operation by the United States to evacuate at-risk Afghan civilians, such as interpreters, embassy employees, and Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants, from Afghanistan. The operation is part of the larger American military withdrawal from the country. The operation's name was officially unveiled by the Biden administration on July 14.

On July 30, 2021, the first group of 200 Afghan interpreters arrived at Fort Lee, Virginia, for SIV processing. As of August 22, the United States has evacuated 17,000 people, including 2,500 Americans, from Afghanistan in the past few weeks. This comes after the Biden administration announced that 3,000 U.S. troops would be deployed to secure the evacuation of embassy personnel, U.S. nationals, and SIV applicants at the Kabul International Airport, following the Taliban's takeover of the country.

The U.S. military took control of air traffic at the airport on August 15, and on August 16, a C-17 cargo plane evacuated roughly 823 people to the Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar. The head of U.S. Central Command, General Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr., met with Taliban leaders based in Doha, and they agreed to the terms set by McKenzie for refugees to flee using Kabul Airport.

On August 17, approximately 1,100 people were evacuated on 13 flights, and by August 19, over 7,000 people had been evacuated, including nearly 2,000 Afghan interpreters flown to the U.S. for SIV processing. On August 20, over 12,700 people had been evacuated, and the Department of Defense activated the Civil Reserve Air Fleet to assist in the evacuation, with 18 planes consisting of commercial airline pilots and crews transporting Afghans from U.S. bases in the Middle East to Europe and ultimately the United States.

However, the evacuation efforts have been marred by casualties, including at least eight people who were killed at the Kabul International Airport as thousands of people tried to forcibly board planes. At least two people clung to the landing gear of a departing C-17 cargo plane, falling to their deaths, while at least three people clinging to the side of an Air Force jet were killed. Remains of another dead Afghan were found in the landing gear of the American C-17 after an emergency landing in a nearby country. Two armed men who fired into a crowd were also killed by U.S. troops.

Solar cycle 25 started in December 2019 with a smoothed minimum sunspot number of 1.8 and is expected to continue until about 2030. While initial predictions regarding its strength varied widely, the Solar Cycle 25 Prediction Panel predicted in December 2019 that it will be similar to solar cycle 24, which was weaker than average. The panel expects the number of sunspots to reach a (smoothed) maximum of 115 in July 2025 (± 8 months), which is in line with current general agreement in the scientific literature.

Recent activity suggests that solar cycle 25 is ongoing, including the appearance of two reversed polarity sunspots in November 2019 and reversed polarity sunspots suggesting a transition to cycle 25 from December 2016 or early April 2018. Nandy et al. analyzed the polarity orientation of bipolar magnetic regions observed in December 2019 and concluded that magnetic regions with the underlying orientation of solar cycle 25's toroidal field component were brewing in the solar convection zone, representing early signs of the new cycle.

Solar activity has steadily increased since May 2020, with the first C-class and M-class solar flares of the cycle occurring that month. Flares continued to take place on a near-daily basis by November, with an M4.4 flare, the strongest of the cycle to date, occurring on November 29, possibly indicating that the solar cycle would be more active than initially thought. The first X-class solar flare of the cycle happened on July 3, but it was not directed towards Earth. Six sunspots were seen for the first time since September 6, 2017 on July 22. On October 9, a M1.6 class solar flare erupted, sending a coronal mass ejection that hit Earth on October 12, triggering a G2 Geomagnetic Storm.

More recently, an X-class solar flare, the second of the current solar cycle, erupted, and an associated coronal mass ejection may graze Earth on October 30 or 31. This event could cause bright aurorae and interfere with satellite communications.

Israel's vaccination program, dubbed "Give a Shoulder," has been widely praised for its success in rapidly vaccinating a large proportion of its population. As of June 26, 2021, around 64% of eligible Israelis had received at least one dose of the vaccine, with 60% having received both doses, placing Israel at the forefront of countries with the highest vaccination rates per capita. The program was marked by coordinated drives and the use of personal information databases to target eligible populations, as well as by the centralized systems of the country's health maintenance organizations. The first vaccinations, which began on December 19, 2020, were allocated to the elderly and healthcare workers, with more than 85% of healthcare workers at one hospital in Jerusalem (Hadassah Hebrew University Medical Center) receiving their vaccinations after eight weeks. 

The success of the vaccination program led to the introduction of a "green pass" system in February, which immunized residents show to gain access to certain locations, such as gyms, hotels, and theaters. The green pass represents proof of immunization against COVID-19, through vaccination or previous infection, and is issued to those who have received both doses of the vaccine, with an expiration date six months after issue. By March 2021, at least 50% of the Israeli population had received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine.

However, the program was not without its challenges. Israeli authorities initially faced difficulty with scheduling appointments and interpreting eligibility requirements, which led to disparities in vaccine distribution to less-populated villages and Arab-Israeli communities. During the first quarter of 2021, vaccine hesitancy was also identified among the general population and particular subgroups, such as young adults and religious/cultural minorities. To address this, the government employed a mix of messaging, incentives, and extensions to the original delivery system to increase vaccine coverage from 40 to 60% and beyond.

The issue of vaccine distribution to Palestinians also became a concern, with the Palestinian Authority receiving only enough doses for around 6,000 people through the first quarter of 2021. Although Israel provided vaccines to Israeli citizens of any origin and Palestinian residents in East Jerusalem, an estimated five million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza were ineligible due to oversight by the Palestinian Authority. In June 2021, Israel announced its intention to give over one million Pfizer vaccines set to expire soon to the Palestinian Authority in exchange for future doses. However, the deal fell through after the Palestinian Authority declined due to the vaccines' expiration date.

In further developments, Israel's pandemic advisory board recently approved the use of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for children between five and eleven years old, paving the way for their vaccination.

The 2021–2022 European windstorm season marks the seventh instance of seasonal European windstorm naming. This season sees Greece, Israel, and Cyprus join in naming storms that affect their areas, alongside Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Malta. The storm names for this season were released on September 1, 2021, and include names from the national meteorological agencies of the United Kingdom, Ireland, the Netherlands, France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg.

The first major storm of the season, named Storm Athina by Hellenic National Meteorological Service, caused record-breaking rainfall in Liguria, Italy, on October 8, and led to flooding and power outages in Corfu, Greece. Storm Ballos, also named by Hellenic National Meteorological Service, caused heavy rain and floods in Athens on October 15 and affected several islands. 

On October 16, a storm named Hendrik by the Free University of Berlin developed over the northern Atlantic Ocean and merged with another developing low South of Ireland named Aurore by Meteo France on October 20. The resulting storm, which caused widespread disruption and several fatalities, was later named Aurore/Hendrik.

Cyclone Apollo, a Mediterranean tropical-like cyclone, hit several Mediterranean coast countries, including Tunisia, Algeria, Malta, and Italy, killing at least 5 people and leaving 2 others missing due to flooding from the cyclone. The storm caused heavy rainfall and flooding in Sicily, where the worst of the effects were felt. On November 5, a low named Blas by the Spanish Meteorological Agency (AEMET) affected the Balearic Islands and Catalonia with high winds and heavy rain.

On November 25, Storm Arwen hit the British Isles, causing travel disruptions, widespread damage, and power outages. Three people were reported killed in the United Kingdom, with 100,000 people losing power. 

The season runs until August 31, 2022, and includes storms named by meteorological organizations in Europe and former Atlantic hurricanes that retain their names as assigned by the National Hurricane Center of the United States.

Since 1818, various significant eruptions have occurred, with the latest explosive eruptions being reported from 2014 onwards, accompanied by pyroclastic flows, eruption columns and debris avalanches. While Iceland objected to this moratorium, it continued to maintain a whaling fleet, with one company specializing in catching fin whales and the other catching minke whales. However, in 2020, the hunting of minke whales for domestic consumption was ended as it was no longer popular with tourists.

The decreasing price of whale meat has also contributed to the decision to end whaling. 

Iceland has a whale watching sector that will likely benefit from this decision as it exists in tension with the whaling industry. Operation Unifier, also known as Canadian Armed Forces Joint Task Force-Ukraine, has seen a significant change in its operations as Canada withdraws its military advisors from Ukraine and relocates them to an undisclosed location in Europe. Canada has been a major contributor to the operation, with about 200 Canadian soldiers providing training and support to the Ukrainian Armed Forces, rotating every 6 months.

The broader mission of Operation Unifier includes helping the development of the region, maintaining security, maintaining democracy, providing humanitarian aid, and promoting economic stability and growth. Several commanders have led the operation, with Lieutenant Colonel Sarah Heer currently in charge.

Despite the positive response from members of the Ukrainian diaspora in Canada, who have welcomed the country's contribution to reforming the Ukrainian military, Canada's recent move to withdraw its military advisors and relocate its diplomatic staff has raised concerns about the security situation in Ukraine. The Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation of the European Union and Euratom has been confirmed by the European Court of Justice as compliant with the treaties of the European Union. Poland and Hungary had launched legal proceedings against the regulation, challenging its legal basis. The ruling means that the European Commission is now able to suspend funds from the EU budget to member states that violate rule of law principles, likely to impact the management of EU finances. The regulation requires adherence to principles of legality, transparency, accountability, democratic and pluralistic law-making, legal certainty, effective judicial protection, separation of powers, non-discrimination, and equality before the law, as enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. The European Parliament adopted a resolution in March 2021 calling for the implementation of the Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation, which cannot be subject to adoption of guidelines. The Commission's failure to provide information led to the European Parliament's threat to start legal action. The European Commission rejected the Parliament's ultimatum to fulfil its obligations on the Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation, prompting further legal action.

Australia maintains a list of designated terrorist organisations, which are organisations that have been designated by the Australian government as terrorist organisations as part of the fight against terrorism worldwide. The list is created and maintained by the Attorney-General's Department, and listing, de-listing, and re-listing of terrorist organisations follows a protocol that involves the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Attorney-General's Department. The Australian government currently lists 26 foreign organisations as terrorist organisations, including the recently designated Atomwaffen Division, Tahrir al-Sham, and the Guardians of Religion Organization, as well as the previously listed entirety of Hamas, including its political wing.

Under the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002, it is illegal to materially support or be supported by a listed terrorist organisation, and financing terrorism is also illegal under Division 103 of the Criminal Code Act 1995. The Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) monitors financial transactions involving listed terrorist organisations to prevent the financing of terrorism.

Australian anti-terrorism financing laws also include several sections of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Cth) and the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945 (Cth), which sanction persons and entities under Australian and international law. Prosecutions for these offences rest with the Australian Federal Police, state police forces, and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions.
